page.title: 07SOILS OF FELTWELL
page.content: The earliest settlement at Feltwell was built on the edge of the chalk escarpment where it sloped gently down to what was then marshy fen, suitable only for rough grazing in summer and for cutting peat as fuel. The economy was pastoral until changing agricultural needs brought in arable crops to the chalklands. Draining of the fens began in the 17th century but it was not until the Second World War that much of the black fen was finally cleared of scrub to become some of the richest land in the country. The peat has wasted away so much that much land is now below sea level and farmers plough up the fen clay which was the seat earth for the forests which grew in the district in prehistoric times. The trees which formed the peat are often ploughed up and are called 'bog oak' by local farmers.
